item.title: Experience Calculator Help
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Ags Rush, post:13, topic:422680”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=525339.msg3824818#msg3824818 date=1322087518]

Don’t listen to Native^, only use those types when your information is dynamic.

You can loop through an array just as easy as an ArrayList.

But I think what your question means is that you want a TextField or whatever they are called, and then on the button press you use its getText() method.

if i have a choice to use an arraylist, i never use an arraylist
[/quote]Huh? I can’t tell if that’s a typo or supposed to be a witty reply

Revised with a little help from this tutorial:

http://www.dreamincode.net/forums/topic/17705-basic-gui-concepts/

[code]import java.awt.;
import javax.swing.;
import java.awt.event.*;

public class Experience extends JFrame {
private static final int WIDTH = 400;
private static final int HEIGHT = 300;

private JLabel monsterL, experienceL, totalL;
private JTextField monsterTF, experienceTF, totalTF;
private JButton calculateB, exitB;

//Button Handlers
private CalculateButtonHandler cbHandler;
private ExitButtonHandler ebHandler;

public Experience() {

	monsterL = new JLabel("Exp Per Monster: ", SwingConstants.RIGHT);
	experienceL = new JLabel("Total Monsters: ", SwingConstants.RIGHT);
	totalL = new JLabel("Total Experience: ", SwingConstants.RIGHT);

	monsterTF = new JTextField(10);
	experienceTF = new JTextField(10);
	totalTF = new JTextField(10);

	//Specify handlers for each button and add (register) Action Listeners to each button
	calculateB = new JButton("Calculate");
	cbHandler = new CalculateButtonHandler();
	calculateB.addActionListener(cbHandler);
	exitB = new JButton("Exit");
	ebHandler = new ExitButtonHandler();
	exitB.addActionListener(ebHandler);

	setTitle("Zach's Monster Calculator");
	Container pane = getContentPane();
	pane.setLayout(new GridLayout(4, 2));

	//Add things to the pane in the order you want them to appear (left to right, top to bottom)
	pane.add(monsterL);
	pane.add(monsterTF);
	pane.add(experienceL);
	pane.add(experienceTF);
	pane.add(totalL);
	pane.add(totalTF);
	pane.add(calculateB);
	pane.add(exitB);

	setSize(WIDTH, HEIGHT);
	setVisible(true);
	setDefaultCloseOperation(EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
}

private class CalculateButtonHandler implements ActionListener {
	public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
		double monster, experience, total;

		monster = Double.parseDouble(monsterTF.getText()); //We use the getText and setText methods to manipulate the data entered into those fields.
		experience = Double.parseDouble(experienceTF.getText());
		total = monster * experience;

		totalTF.setText("" + total);
	}
}

public class ExitButtonHandler implements ActionListener {
	public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
		System.exit(0);
	}
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
	Experience experObj = new Experience();
}

}[/code][/quote]
//Button Handlers
private CalculateButtonHandler cbHandler;
private ExitButtonHandler ebHandler;

a kitten fucking died.

Read full topic

item.title: Experience Calculator Help
item.dc:creator: @Ags_Rush Ags Rush
item.description:
@Ags_Rush wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:12, topic:422680”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=525339.msg3824782#msg3824782 date=1322084956]

Don’t listen to Native^, only use those types when your information is dynamic.

You can loop through an array just as easy as an ArrayList.

But I think what your question means is that you want a TextField or whatever they are called, and then on the button press you use its getText() method.

if i have a choice to use an arraylist, i never use an arraylist
[/quote]Huh? I can’t tell if that’s a typo or supposed to be a witty reply :|[/quote]

Revised with a little help from this tutorial:

http://www.dreamincode.net/forums/topic/17705-basic-gui-concepts/

[code]import java.awt.;
import javax.swing.;
import java.awt.event.*;

public class Experience extends JFrame {
private static final int WIDTH = 400;
private static final int HEIGHT = 300;

private JLabel monsterL, experienceL, totalL;
private JTextField monsterTF, experienceTF, totalTF;
private JButton calculateB, exitB;

//Button Handlers
private CalculateButtonHandler cbHandler;
private ExitButtonHandler ebHandler;

public Experience() {

	monsterL = new JLabel("Exp Per Monster: ", SwingConstants.RIGHT);
	experienceL = new JLabel("Total Monsters: ", SwingConstants.RIGHT);
	totalL = new JLabel("Total Experience: ", SwingConstants.RIGHT);

	monsterTF = new JTextField(10);
	experienceTF = new JTextField(10);
	totalTF = new JTextField(10);

	//Specify handlers for each button and add (register) Action Listeners to each button
	calculateB = new JButton("Calculate");
	cbHandler = new CalculateButtonHandler();
	calculateB.addActionListener(cbHandler);
	exitB = new JButton("Exit");
	ebHandler = new ExitButtonHandler();
	exitB.addActionListener(ebHandler);

	setTitle("Zach's Monster Calculator");
	Container pane = getContentPane();
	pane.setLayout(new GridLayout(4, 2));

	//Add things to the pane in the order you want them to appear (left to right, top to bottom)
	pane.add(monsterL);
	pane.add(monsterTF);
	pane.add(experienceL);
	pane.add(experienceTF);
	pane.add(totalL);
	pane.add(totalTF);
	pane.add(calculateB);
	pane.add(exitB);

	setSize(WIDTH, HEIGHT);
	setVisible(true);
	setDefaultCloseOperation(EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
}

private class CalculateButtonHandler implements ActionListener {
	public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
		double monster, experience, total;

		monster = Double.parseDouble(monsterTF.getText()); //We use the getText and setText methods to manipulate the data entered into those fields.
		experience = Double.parseDouble(experienceTF.getText());
		total = monster * experience;

		totalTF.setText("" + total);
	}
}

public class ExitButtonHandler implements ActionListener {
	public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
		System.exit(0);
	}
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
	Experience experObj = new Experience();
}

}[/code]

item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Why would you ever use an integer to replace a monster name?

Basically what you have right now is terrible. You should create a real GUI with a menu or list or something, and populate it with your arrays. Not make them type in the name.

@Native1 wrote:

You should store the data in an ArrayList or anything Genericish, use a loop through it, and let it return when the name of String input is equal to the String of the position of the array.

item.title: Experience Calculator Help
item.dc:creator: @Ags_Rush Ags Rush
item.description:
@Ags_Rush wrote:

[code]import javax.swing.JOptionPane;

public class Experience {

/* Main Method */
public static void main(String[] args) {

	/* Main Experience Array */
	public static int ExperienceArray[][] = {
			{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7}, //Monster ID
			{20, 40, 90, 85, 50, 30}, //Monster Experience
		};

	/* Monster Array */
	public static String[] MonsterName = {"Rock Crabs", "Green Dragons", "Blue Dragons", "Dagganoths", "Flesh Crawlers", "Man", "King Black Dragon"};

	/* Strings, Ints, Doubles */
	String Experience, Monsters;
	int Exp, Monster;
	double total, index;

	/* Inputs */
	JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(null, "Zach's Experience Calculator");
	JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(null, "Rock Crabs, Green Dragons, Blue Dragons, Dagganoths, Flesh Crawlers, Man, King Black Dragon, are the only monsters supported right now.");
	Experience = JOptionPane.showInputDialog(null, "Enter the name of the monster you would like to know the exp for.");
	Exp = Integer.parseInt(ExperienceArray);
	Monsters = JOptionPane.showInputDialog(null, "Enter the number of Monsters you will be killing");
	Monster = Integer.parseInt(Monsters);

	/* Calculations */
	total = Exp * Monster;
	index = total;

	/* Output */
	JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(null, "The total amount of experience you will be getting is" + index + ".");
	System.exit(0);
}

}
[/code]

Instead of Integer.parseInt(string)

What would i use so that the user can input the name of a monster?

Read full topic
